never_claim: That cJSON has streaming JSON parsing
That cJSON supports JSON5, comments, or non-standard JSON
That cJSON has schema validation capabilities
That cJSON provides thread safety guarantees
That cJSON uses iterative parsing instead of recursive descent
That cJSON performs in-place serialization without allocation
That cJSON is reentrant or free of global state
That cJSON can safely mutate trees without caller-managed memory
That cJSON handles extremely large JSON documents efficiently
That cJSON supports incremental DOM updates automatically
That cJSON is exception-safe or returns error codes
That cJSON can parse streams or file handles directly
That cJSON owns memory allocated by the caller
That cJSON includes reference counting or GC
That cJSON has built-in UTF-8 validation or Unicode normalization
never_infer: New APIs that do not appear in the official cJSON distribution
Struct fields or layout changes not explicitly present in the real headers
Background threads, event loops, or async features
truth_rules: Must not invent functions, macros, or struct members
Must not imply safety guarantees not provided by the actual library
Must not describe memory semantics other than caller-owned nodes and strings
Must not imply optional dependencies or external libraries
All claims about behavior must be verifiable from the official cJSON source
Must admit uncertainty when behavior is ambiguous or unsupported

honesty_enforcement.structural_truth: Json node struct layout must match the real implementation
honesty_enforcement.memory_truth: Node ownership and allocation semantics must be followed
honesty_enforcement.error_truth: Only the documented global error pointer is used for parse errors
